newsitem.title: CHILE: Software piracy rife in Latin America - study.
newsitem.headline: Software piracy rife in Latin America - study.

text.p: Nearly seven of every 10 computer software programmes sold in Latin America is an illegal copy of an original one, a study by the accounting firm Price Waterhouse said on Thursday.

Pirating of computer software in Latin America reaches more than 90 percent of software sales in some countries, but is still less in the region as a whole than in Eastern Europe, where 80 percent of computer software is pirated, the study said.
"The results of our study show that of every 100 copies of software sold in Latin America, 68 are pirated," Price Waterhouse researcher Guillermo Beuchat told reporters.
By comparison, 28 percent of computer software programmes sold in North America are pirated, 43 percent in Western Europe and 74 percent in the Middle East, the study said.
Sales of illegally copied software totalled about $911 million in Latin America last year, according to a study by the trade group Business Software Alliance that was cited in the report.

Pirating rates reach their highest level in Central America, where 92 percent of programmes sold in El Salvador are pirated and 90 percent in Guatemala. Costa Rica, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago are not far behind.
Argentina, which has a hot trade dispute with the United States over intellectual property laws, has a pirating rate of about 70 percent and Brazil's rate is about 68 percent, the study said.
The lowest pirating rates in the region are in Chile, with 62 percent, and Panama at 65 percent, the study said.
Software piracy cost Latin American government treasuries about $5 billion in lost tax receipts and nearly 115,000 jobs, Beuchat said.
